description: SkiSlo is a research project by Alta Scuola Politecnica, Politecnico di Milano and Politecnico di Torino, in collaboration with Fondazione Matilde Lorenzi. It develops AI-driven digital twin models and slope mapping technologies to predict and reduce ski accidents, creating safer and smarter ski environments.

Mission.1: SkiSlo is a research project dedicated to enhancing skier safety, with a specific focus on identifying the main hazards faced by professional and competitive athletes.
Mission.3: The project develops a high-fidelity slope mapping system based on a Digital Surface Model (DSM) and integrates a snowpack data analysis tool. It also includes a dynamic skier model to simulate the interaction between athletes and slope conditions. Using this data, SkiSlo performs advanced simulations to identify dangerous areas through risk function optimization, producing detailed risk maps that highlight potential hazards by zone or sector.
Mission.5: The ultimate goal is to validate these simulations and apply the developed tools to real-world ski facilities, helping them adopt effective safety measures and reduce both the number and severity of accidents. SkiSlo aims to create a tool that translates the results of its risk models into practical safety guidelines for ski facilities and federations.
Mission.7: SkiSlo was born from tragedy. During a training session in Val Senales, Matilde Lorenzi suffered a fatal accident. Her family established the Fondazione Matilde Lorenzi to promote ski safety and prevention initiatives, ensuring that athletes can train in safer environments. SkiSlo embraced this mission, developing innovative technologies to minimize risks and reshape the future of skiing — so that no athlete must face the same fate as Matilde.
